speaker: BEDFORD
line: Hung be the heavens with black, yield day to night!

speaker: BEDFORD
line: Comets, importing change of times and states,

speaker: BEDFORD
line: Brandish your crystal tresses in the sky,

speaker: BEDFORD
line: And with them scourge the bad revolting stars

speaker: BEDFORD
line: That have consented unto Henry's death!

speaker: BEDFORD
line: King Henry the Fifth, too famous to live long!

speaker: BEDFORD
line: England ne'er lost a king of so much worth.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
line: England ne'er had a king until his time.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
line: Virtue he had, deserving to command:

speaker: GLOUCESTER
line: His brandish'd sword did blind men with his beams:

speaker: GLOUCESTER
line: His arms spread wider than a dragon's wings;

speaker: GLOUCESTER
line: His sparking eyes, replete with wrathful fire,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
line: More dazzled and drove back his enemies

speaker: GLOUCESTER
line: Than mid-day sun fierce bent against their faces.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
line: What should I say? his deeds exceed all speech:

speaker: GLOUCESTER
line: He ne'er lift up his hand but conquered.

speaker: EXETER
line: We mourn in black: why mourn we not in blood?

speaker: EXETER
line: Henry is dead and never shall revive:

speaker: EXETER
line: Upon a wooden coffin we attend,

speaker: EXETER
line: And death's dishonourable victory

speaker: EXETER
line: We with our stately presence glorify,

speaker: EXETER
line: Like captives bound to a triumphant car.

speaker: EXETER
line: What! shall we curse the planets of mishap

speaker: EXETER
line: That plotted thus our glory's overthrow?

speaker: EXETER
line: Or shall we think the subtle-witted French

speaker: EXETER
line: Conjurers and sorcerers, that afraid of him

speaker: EXETER
line: By magic verses have contrived his end?

speaker: BISHOP OF WINCHESTER
line: He was a king bless'd of the King of kings.

speaker: BISHOP OF WINCHESTER
line: Unto the French the dreadful judgement-day

speaker: BISHOP OF WINCHESTER
line: So dreadful will not be as was his sight.

speaker: BISHOP OF WINCHESTER
line: The battles of the Lord of hosts he fought:

speaker: BISHOP OF WINCHESTER
line: The church's prayers made him so prosperous.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
line: The church! where is it? Had not churchmen pray'd,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
line: His thread of life had not so soon decay'd:

speaker: GLOUCESTER
line: None do you like but an effeminate prince,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
line: Whom, like a school-boy, you may over-awe.

speaker: BISHOP OF WINCHESTER
line: Gloucester, whate'er we like, thou art protector

speaker: BISHOP OF WINCHESTER
line: And lookest to command the prince and realm.

speaker: BISHOP OF WINCHESTER
line: Thy wife is proud; she holdeth thee in awe,

speaker: BISHOP OF WINCHESTER
line: More than God or religious churchmen may.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
line: Name not religion, for thou lovest the flesh,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
line: And ne'er throughout the year to church thou go'st

speaker: GLOUCESTER
line: Except it be to pray against thy foes.

speaker: BEDFORD
line: Cease, cease these jars and rest your minds in peace:

speaker: BEDFORD
line: Let's to the altar: heralds, wait on us:

speaker: BEDFORD
line: Instead of gold, we'll offer up our arms:

speaker: BEDFORD
line: Since arms avail not now that Henry's dead.

speaker: BEDFORD
line: Posterity, await for wretched years,

speaker: BEDFORD
line: When at their mothers' moist eyes babes shall suck,

speaker: BEDFORD
line: Our isle be made a nourish of salt tears,

speaker: BEDFORD
line: And none but women left to wail the dead.

speaker: BEDFORD
line: Henry the Fifth, thy ghost I invocate:

speaker: BEDFORD
line: Prosper this realm, keep it from civil broils,

speaker: BEDFORD
line: Combat with adverse planets in the heavens!

speaker: BEDFORD
line: A far more glorious star thy soul will make

speaker: BEDFORD
line: Than Julius Caesar or bright--

speaker: Messenger
line: My honourable lords, health to you all!

speaker: Messenger
line: Sad tidings bring I to you out of France,

speaker: Messenger
line: Of loss, of slaughter and discomfiture:

speaker: Messenger
line: Guienne, Champagne, Rheims, Orleans,

speaker: Messenger
line: Paris, Guysors, Poictiers, are all quite lost.

speaker: BEDFORD
line: What say'st thou, man, before dead Henry's corse?

speaker: BEDFORD
line: Speak softly, or the loss of those great towns

speaker: BEDFORD
line: Will make him burst his lead and rise from death.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
line: Is Paris lost? is Rouen yielded up?

speaker: GLOUCESTER
line: If Henry were recall'd to life again,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
line: These news would cause him once more yield the ghost.

speaker: EXETER
line: How were they lost? what treachery was used?

speaker: Messenger
line: No treachery; but want of men and money.

speaker: Messenger
line: Amongst the soldiers this is muttered,

speaker: Messenger
line: That here you maintain several factions,

speaker: Messenger
line: And whilst a field should be dispatch'd and fought,

speaker: Messenger
line: You are disputing of your generals:

speaker: Messenger
line: One would have lingering wars with little cost;

speaker: Messenger
line: Another would fly swift, but wanteth wings;

speaker: Messenger
line: A third thinks, without expense at all,

speaker: Messenger
line: By guileful fair words peace may be obtain'd.

speaker: Messenger
line: Awake, awake, English nobility!

speaker: Messenger
line: Let not sloth dim your horrors new-begot:

speaker: Messenger
line: Cropp'd are the flower-de-luces in your arms;

speaker: Messenger
line: Of England's coat one half is cut away.

speaker: EXETER
line: Were our tears wanting to this funeral,

speaker: EXETER
line: These tidings would call forth their flowing tides.

speaker: BEDFORD
line: Me they concern; Regent I am of France.

speaker: BEDFORD
line: Give me my steeled coat. I'll fight for France.

speaker: BEDFORD
line: Away with these disgraceful wailing robes!

speaker: BEDFORD
line: Wounds will I lend the French instead of eyes,

speaker: BEDFORD
line: To weep their intermissive miseries.

speaker: Messenger
line: Lords, view these letters full of bad mischance.

speaker: Messenger
line: France is revolted from the English quite,

speaker: Messenger
line: Except some petty towns of no import:

speaker: Messenger
line: The Dauphin Charles is crowned king of Rheims;

speaker: Messenger
line: The Bastard of Orleans with him is join'd;

speaker: Messenger
line: Reignier, Duke of Anjou, doth take his part;

speaker: Messenger
line: The Duke of Alencon flieth to his side.

speaker: EXETER
line: The Dauphin crowned king! all fly to him!

speaker: EXETER
line: O, whither shall we fly from this reproach?

speaker: GLOUCESTER
line: We will not fly, but to our enemies' throats.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
line: Bedford, if thou be slack, I'll fight it out.

speaker: BEDFORD
line: Gloucester, why doubt'st thou of my forwardness?

speaker: BEDFORD
line: An army have I muster'd in my thoughts,

speaker: BEDFORD
line: Wherewith already France is overrun.

speaker: Messenger
line: My gracious lords, to add to your laments,

speaker: Messenger
line: Wherewith you now bedew King Henry's hearse,

speaker: Messenger
line: I must inform you of a dismal fight

speaker: Messenger
line: Betwixt the stout Lord Talbot and the French.

speaker: BISHOP OF WINCHESTER
line: What! wherein Talbot overcame? is't so?

speaker: Messenger
line: O, no; wherein Lord Talbot was o'erthrown:

speaker: Messenger
line: The circumstance I'll tell you more at large.

speaker: Messenger
line: The tenth of August last this dreadful lord,

speaker: Messenger
line: Retiring from the siege of Orleans,

speaker: Messenger
line: Having full scarce six thousand in his troop.

speaker: Messenger
line: By three and twenty thousand of the French

speaker: Messenger
line: Was round encompassed and set upon.

speaker: Messenger
line: No leisure had he to enrank his men;

speaker: Messenger
line: He wanted pikes to set before his archers;

speaker: Messenger
line: Instead whereof sharp stakes pluck'd out of hedges

speaker: Messenger
line: They pitched in the ground confusedly,

speaker: Messenger
line: To keep the horsemen off from breaking in.

speaker: Messenger
line: More than three hours the fight continued;

speaker: Messenger
line: Where valiant Talbot above human thought

speaker: Messenger
line: Enacted wonders with his sword and lance:

speaker: Messenger
line: Hundreds he sent to hell, and none durst stand him;

speaker: Messenger
line: Here, there, and every where, enraged he flew:

speaker: Messenger
line: The French exclaim'd, the devil was in arms;

speaker: Messenger
line: All the whole army stood agazed on him:

speaker: Messenger
line: His soldiers spying his undaunted spirit

speaker: Messenger
line: A Talbot! a Talbot! cried out amain

speaker: Messenger
line: And rush'd into the bowels of the battle.

speaker: Messenger
line: Here had the conquest fully been seal'd up,

speaker: Messenger
line: If Sir John Fastolfe had not play'd the coward:

speaker: Messenger
line: He, being in the vaward, placed behind

speaker: Messenger
line: With purpose to relieve and follow them,

speaker: Messenger
line: Cowardly fled, not having struck one stroke.

speaker: Messenger
line: Hence grew the general wreck and massacre;

speaker: Messenger
line: Enclosed were they with their enemies:

speaker: Messenger
line: A base Walloon, to win the Dauphin's grace,

speaker: Messenger
line: Thrust Talbot with a spear into the back,

speaker: Messenger
line: Whom all France with their chief assembled strength

speaker: Messenger
line: Durst not presume to look once in the face.

speaker: BEDFORD
line: Is Talbot slain? then I will slay myself,

speaker: BEDFORD
line: For living idly here in pomp and ease,

speaker: BEDFORD
line: Whilst such a worthy leader, wanting aid,

speaker: BEDFORD
line: Unto his dastard foemen is betray'd.

speaker: Messenger
line: O no, he lives; but is took prisoner,

speaker: Messenger
line: And Lord Scales with him and Lord Hungerford:

speaker: Messenger
line: Most of the rest slaughter'd or took likewise.

speaker: BEDFORD
line: His ransom there is none but I shall pay:

speaker: BEDFORD
line: I'll hale the Dauphin headlong from his throne:

speaker: BEDFORD
line: His crown shall be the ransom of my friend;

speaker: BEDFORD
line: Four of their lords I'll change for one of ours.

speaker: BEDFORD
line: Farewell, my masters; to my task will I;

speaker: BEDFORD
line: Bonfires in France forthwith I am to make,

speaker: BEDFORD
line: To keep our great Saint George's feast withal:

speaker: BEDFORD
line: Ten thousand soldiers with me I will take,

speaker: BEDFORD
line: Whose bloody deeds shall make all Europe quake.

speaker: Messenger
line: So you had need; for Orleans is besieged;

speaker: Messenger
line: The English army is grown weak and faint:

speaker: Messenger
line: The Earl of Salisbury craveth supply,

speaker: Messenger
line: And hardly keeps his men from mutiny,

speaker: Messenger
line: Since they, so few, watch such a multitude.

speaker: EXETER
line: Remember, lords, your oaths to Henry sworn,

speaker: EXETER
line: Either to quell the Dauphin utterly,

speaker: EXETER
line: Or bring him in obedience to your yoke.

speaker: BEDFORD
line: I do remember it; and here take my leave,

speaker: BEDFORD
line: To go about my preparation.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
line: I'll to the Tower with all the haste I can,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
line: To view the artillery and munition;

speaker: GLOUCESTER
line: And then I will proclaim young Henry king.

speaker: EXETER
line: To Eltham will I, where the young king is,

speaker: EXETER
line: Being ordain'd his special governor,

speaker: EXETER
line: And for his safety there I'll best devise.

speaker: BISHOP OF WINCHESTER
line: Each hath his place and function to attend:

speaker: BISHOP OF WINCHESTER
line: I am left out; for me nothing remains.

speaker: BISHOP OF WINCHESTER
line: But long I will not be Jack out of office:

speaker: BISHOP OF WINCHESTER
line: The king from Eltham I intend to steal

speaker: BISHOP OF WINCHESTER
line: And sit at chiefest stern of public weal.

speaker: CHARLES
line: Mars his true moving, even as in the heavens

speaker: CHARLES
line: So in the earth, to this day is not known:

speaker: CHARLES
line: Late did he shine upon the English side;

speaker: CHARLES
line: Now we are victors; upon us he smiles.

speaker: CHARLES
line: What towns of any moment but we have?

speaker: CHARLES
line: At pleasure here we lie near Orleans;

speaker: CHARLES
line: Otherwhiles the famish'd English, like pale ghosts,

speaker: CHARLES
line: Faintly besiege us one hour in a month.

speaker: ALENCON
line: They want their porridge and their fat bull-beeves:

speaker: ALENCON
line: Either they must be dieted like mules

speaker: ALENCON
line: And have their provender tied to their mouths

speaker: ALENCON
line: Or piteous they will look, like drowned mice.

speaker: REIGNIER
line: Let's raise the siege: why live we idly here?

speaker: REIGNIER
line: Talbot is taken, whom we wont to fear:

speaker: REIGNIER
line: Remaineth none but mad-brain'd Salisbury;

speaker: REIGNIER
line: And he may well in fretting spend his gall,

speaker: REIGNIER
line: Nor men nor money hath he to make war.

speaker: CHARLES
line: Sound, sound alarum! we will rush on them.

speaker: CHARLES
line: Now for the honour of the forlorn French!

speaker: CHARLES
line: Him I forgive my death that killeth me

speaker: CHARLES
line: When he sees me go back one foot or fly.

speaker: CHARLES
line: Who ever saw the like? what men have I!

speaker: CHARLES
line: Dogs! cowards! dastards! I would ne'er have fled,

speaker: CHARLES
line: But that they left me 'midst my enemies.

speaker: REIGNIER
line: Salisbury is a desperate homicide;

speaker: REIGNIER
line: He fighteth as one weary of his life.

speaker: REIGNIER
line: The other lords, like lions wanting food,

speaker: REIGNIER
line: Do rush upon us as their hungry prey.

speaker: ALENCON
line: Froissart, a countryman of ours, records,

speaker: ALENCON
line: England all Olivers and Rowlands bred,

speaker: ALENCON
line: During the time Edward the Third did reign.

speaker: ALENCON
line: More truly now may this be verified;

speaker: ALENCON
line: For none but Samsons and Goliases

speaker: ALENCON
line: It sendeth forth to skirmish. One to ten!

speaker: ALENCON
line: Lean, raw-boned rascals! who would e'er suppose

speaker: ALENCON
line: They had such courage and audacity?

speaker: CHARLES
line: Let's leave this town; for they are hare-brain'd slaves,

speaker: CHARLES
line: And hunger will enforce them to be more eager:

speaker: CHARLES
line: Of old I know them; rather with their teeth

speaker: CHARLES
line: The walls they'll tear down than forsake the siege.

speaker: REIGNIER
line: I think, by some odd gimmors or device

speaker: REIGNIER
line: Their arms are set like clocks, stiff to strike on;

speaker: REIGNIER
line: Else ne'er could they hold out so as they do.

speaker: REIGNIER
line: By my consent, we'll even let them alone.

speaker: ALENCON
line: Be it so.

speaker: BASTARD OF ORLEANS
line: Where's the Prince Dauphin? I have news for him.

speaker: CHARLES
line: Bastard of Orleans, thrice welcome to us.

speaker: BASTARD OF ORLEANS
line: Methinks your looks are sad, your cheer appall'd:

speaker: BASTARD OF ORLEANS
line: Hath the late overthrow wrought this offence?

speaker: BASTARD OF ORLEANS
line: Be not dismay'd, for succor is at hand:

speaker: BASTARD OF ORLEANS
line: A holy maid hither with me I bring,

speaker: BASTARD OF ORLEANS
line: Which by a vision sent to her from heaven

speaker: BASTARD OF ORLEANS
line: Ordained is to raise this tedious siege

speaker: BASTARD OF ORLEANS
line: And drive the English forth the bounds of France.

speaker: BASTARD OF ORLEANS
line: The spirit of deep prophecy she hath,

speaker: BASTARD OF ORLEANS
line: Exceeding the nine sibyls of old Rome:

speaker: BASTARD OF ORLEANS
line: What's past and what's to come she can descry.

speaker: BASTARD OF ORLEANS
line: Speak, shall I call her in? Believe my words,

speaker: BASTARD OF ORLEANS
line: For they are certain and unfallible.

speaker: CHARLES
line: Go, call her in.

speaker: CHARLES
line: But first, to try her skill,

speaker: CHARLES
line: Reignier, stand thou as Dauphin in my place:

speaker: CHARLES
line: Question her proudly; let thy looks be stern:

speaker: CHARLES
line: By this means shall we sound what skill she hath.

speaker: REIGNIER
line: Fair maid, is't thou wilt do these wondrous feats?

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
line: Reignier, is't thou that thinkest to beguile me?

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
line: Where is the Dauphin? Come, come from behind;

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
line: I know thee well, though never seen before.

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
line: Be not amazed, there's nothing hid from me:

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
line: In private will I talk with thee apart.

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
line: Stand back, you lords, and give us leave awhile.

speaker: REIGNIER
line: She takes upon her bravely at first dash.

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
line: Dauphin, I am by birth a shepherd's daughter,

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
line: My wit untrain'd in any kind of art.

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
line: Heaven and our Lady gracious hath it pleased

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
line: To shine on my contemptible estate:

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
line: Lo, whilst I waited on my tender lambs,

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
line: And to sun's parching heat display'd my cheeks,

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
line: God's mother deigned to appear to me

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
line: And in a vision full of majesty

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
line: Will'd me to leave my base vocation

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
line: And free my country from calamity:

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
line: Her aid she promised and assured success:

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
line: In complete glory she reveal'd herself;

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
line: And, whereas I was black and swart before,

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
line: With those clear rays which she infused on me

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
line: That beauty am I bless'd with which you see.

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
line: Ask me what question thou canst possible,

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
line: And I will answer unpremeditated:

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
line: My courage try by combat, if thou darest,

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
line: And thou shalt find that I exceed my sex.

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
line: Resolve on this, thou shalt be fortunate,

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
line: If thou receive me for thy warlike mate.

speaker: CHARLES
line: Thou hast astonish'd me with thy high terms:

speaker: CHARLES
line: Only this proof I'll of thy valour make,

speaker: CHARLES
line: In single combat thou shalt buckle with me,

speaker: CHARLES
line: And if thou vanquishest, thy words are true;

speaker: CHARLES
line: Otherwise I renounce all confidence.

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
line: I am prepared: here is my keen-edged sword,

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
line: Deck'd with five flower-de-luces on each side;

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
line: The which at Touraine, in Saint Katharine's

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
line: churchyard,

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
line: Out of a great deal of old iron I chose forth.

speaker: CHARLES
line: Then come, o' God's name; I fear no woman.

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
line: And while I live, I'll ne'er fly from a man.

speaker: CHARLES
line: Stay, stay thy hands! thou art an Amazon

speaker: CHARLES
line: And fightest with the sword of Deborah.

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
line: Christ's mother helps me, else I were too weak.

speaker: CHARLES
line: Whoe'er helps thee, 'tis thou that must help me:

speaker: CHARLES
line: Impatiently I burn with thy desire;

speaker: CHARLES
line: My heart and hands thou hast at once subdued.

speaker: CHARLES
line: Excellent Pucelle, if thy name be so,

speaker: CHARLES
line: Let me thy servant and not sovereign be:

speaker: CHARLES
line: 'Tis the French Dauphin sueth to thee thus.

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
line: I must not yield to any rites of love,

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
line: For my profession's sacred from above:

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
line: When I have chased all thy foes from hence,

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
line: Then will I think upon a recompense.

speaker: CHARLES
line: Meantime look gracious on thy prostrate thrall.

speaker: REIGNIER
line: My lord, methinks, is very long in talk.

speaker: ALENCON
line: Doubtless he shrives this woman to her smock;

speaker: ALENCON
line: Else ne'er could he so long protract his speech.

speaker: REIGNIER
line: Shall we disturb him, since he keeps no mean?

speaker: ALENCON
line: He may mean more than we poor men do know:

speaker: ALENCON
line: These women are shrewd tempters with their tongues.

speaker: REIGNIER
line: My lord, where are you? what devise you on?

speaker: REIGNIER
line: Shall we give over Orleans, or no?

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
line: Why, no, I say, distrustful recreants!

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
line: Fight till the last gasp; I will be your guard.

speaker: CHARLES
line: What she says I'll confirm: we'll fight it out.

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
line: Assign'd am I to be the English scourge.

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
line: This night the siege assuredly I'll raise:

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
line: Expect Saint Martin's summer, halcyon days,

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
line: Since I have entered into these wars.

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
line: Glory is like a circle in the water,

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
line: Which never ceaseth to enlarge itself

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
line: Till by broad spreading it disperse to nought.

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
line: With Henry's death the English circle ends;

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
line: Dispersed are the glories it included.

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
line: Now am I like that proud insulting ship

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
line: Which Caesar and his fortune bare at once.

speaker: CHARLES
line: Was Mahomet inspired with a dove?

speaker: CHARLES
line: Thou with an eagle art inspired then.

speaker: CHARLES
line: Helen, the mother of great Constantine,

speaker: CHARLES
line: Nor yet Saint Philip's daughters, were like thee.

speaker: CHARLES
line: Bright star of Venus, fall'n down on the earth,

speaker: CHARLES
line: How may I reverently worship thee enough?

speaker: ALENCON
line: Leave off delays, and let us raise the siege.

speaker: REIGNIER
line: Woman, do what thou canst to save our honours;

speaker: REIGNIER
line: Drive them from Orleans and be immortalized.

speaker: CHARLES
line: Presently we'll try: come, let's away about it:

speaker: CHARLES
line: No prophet will I trust, if she prove false.

scene: SCENE III.  London. Before the Tower.
speaker: GLOUCESTER
line: I am come to survey the Tower this day:

scene: SCENE III.  London. Before the Tower.
speaker: GLOUCESTER
line: Since Henry's death, I fear, there is conveyance.

scene: SCENE III.  London. Before the Tower.
speaker: GLOUCESTER
line: Where be these warders, that they wait not here?

scene: SCENE III.  London. Before the Tower.
speaker: GLOUCESTER
line: Open the gates; 'tis Gloucester that calls.

scene: SCENE III.  London. Before the Tower.
speaker: First Warder
line: Within  Who's there that knocks so imperiously?

scene: SCENE III.  London. Before the Tower.
speaker: First Serving-Man
line: It is the noble Duke of Gloucester.

scene: SCENE III.  London. Before the Tower.
speaker: Second Warder
line: Within  Whoe'er he be, you may not be let in.

scene: SCENE III.  London. Before the Tower.
speaker: First Serving-Man
line: Villains, answer you so the lord protector?

scene: SCENE III.  London. Before the Tower.
speaker: First Warder
line: Within  The Lord protect him! so we answer him:

scene: SCENE III.  London. Before the Tower.
speaker: First Warder
line: We do no otherwise than we are will'd.

scene: SCENE III.  London. Before the Tower.
speaker: GLOUCESTER
line: Who willed you? or whose will stands but mine?

scene: SCENE III.  London. Before the Tower.
speaker: GLOUCESTER
line: There's none protector of the realm but I.

scene: SCENE III.  London. Before the Tower.
speaker: GLOUCESTER
line: Break up the gates, I'll be your warrantize.

scene: SCENE III.  London. Before the Tower.
speaker: GLOUCESTER
line: Shall I be flouted thus by dunghill grooms?

scene: SCENE III.  London. Before the Tower.
speaker: WOODVILE
line: What noise is this? what traitors have we here?

scene: SCENE III.  London. Before the Tower.
speaker: GLOUCESTER
line: Lieutenant, is it you whose voice I hear?

scene: SCENE III.  London. Before the Tower.
speaker: GLOUCESTER
line: Open the gates; here's Gloucester that would enter.

scene: SCENE III.  London. Before the Tower.
speaker: WOODVILE
line: Have patience, noble duke; I may not open;

scene: SCENE III.  London. Before the Tower.
speaker: WOODVILE
line: The Cardinal of Winchester forbids:

scene: SCENE III.  London. Before the Tower.
speaker: WOODVILE
line: From him I have express commandment

scene: SCENE III.  London. Before the Tower.
speaker: WOODVILE
line: That thou nor none of thine shall be let in.

scene: SCENE III.  London. Before the Tower.
speaker: GLOUCESTER
line: Faint-hearted Woodvile, prizest him 'fore me?

scene: SCENE III.  London. Before the Tower.
speaker: GLOUCESTER
line: Arrogant Winchester, that haughty prelate,

scene: SCENE III.  London. Before the Tower.
speaker: GLOUCESTER
line: Whom Henry, our late sovereign, ne'er could brook?

scene: SCENE III.  London. Before the Tower.
speaker: GLOUCESTER
line: Thou art no friend to God or to the king:

scene: SCENE III.  London. Before the Tower.
speaker: GLOUCESTER
line: Open the gates, or I'll shut thee out shortly.

scene: SCENE III.  London. Before the Tower.
speaker: Serving-Men
line: Open the gates unto the lord protector,

scene: SCENE III.  London. Before the Tower.
speaker: Serving-Men
line: Or we'll burst them open, if that you come not quickly.

scene: SCENE III.  London. Before the Tower.
speaker: BISHOP OF WINCHESTER
line: How now, ambitious Humphry! what means this?

scene: SCENE III.  London. Before the Tower.
speaker: GLOUCESTER
line: Peel'd priest, dost thou command me to be shut out?

scene: SCENE III.  London. Before the Tower.
speaker: BISHOP OF WINCHESTER
line: I do, thou most usurping proditor,

scene: SCENE III.  London. Before the Tower.
speaker: BISHOP OF WINCHESTER
line: And not protector, of the king or realm.

scene: SCENE III.  London. Before the Tower.
speaker: GLOUCESTER
line: Stand back, thou manifest conspirator,

scene: SCENE III.  London. Before the Tower.
speaker: GLOUCESTER
line: Thou that contrivedst to murder our dead lord;

scene: SCENE III.  London. Before the Tower.
speaker: GLOUCESTER
line: Thou that givest whores indulgences to sin:

scene: SCENE III.  London. Before the Tower.
speaker: GLOUCESTER
line: I'll canvass thee in thy broad cardinal's hat,

scene: SCENE III.  London. Before the Tower.
speaker: GLOUCESTER
line: If thou proceed in this thy insolence.

scene: SCENE III.  London. Before the Tower.
speaker: BISHOP OF WINCHESTER
line: Nay, stand thou back, I will not budge a foot:

scene: SCENE III.  London. Before the Tower.
speaker: BISHOP OF WINCHESTER
line: This be Damascus, be thou cursed Cain,

scene: SCENE III.  London. Before the Tower.
speaker: BISHOP OF WINCHESTER
line: To slay thy brother Abel, if thou wilt.

scene: SCENE III.  London. Before the Tower.
speaker: GLOUCESTER
line: I will not slay thee, but I'll drive thee back:

scene: SCENE III.  London. Before the Tower.
speaker: GLOUCESTER
line: Thy scarlet robes as a child's bearing-cloth

scene: SCENE III.  London. Before the Tower.
speaker: GLOUCESTER
line: I'll use to carry thee out of this place.

scene: SCENE III.  London. Before the Tower.
speaker: BISHOP OF WINCHESTER
line: Do what thou darest; I beard thee to thy face.

scene: SCENE III.  London. Before the Tower.
speaker: GLOUCESTER
line: What! am I dared and bearded to my face?

scene: SCENE III.  London. Before the Tower.
speaker: GLOUCESTER
line: Draw, men, for all this privileged place;

scene: SCENE III.  London. Before the Tower.
speaker: GLOUCESTER
line: Blue coats to tawny coats. Priest, beware your beard,

scene: SCENE III.  London. Before the Tower.
speaker: GLOUCESTER
line: I mean to tug it and to cuff you soundly:

scene: SCENE III.  London. Before the Tower.
speaker: GLOUCESTER
line: Under my feet I stamp thy cardinal's hat:

scene: SCENE III.  London. Before the Tower.
speaker: GLOUCESTER
line: In spite of pope or dignities of church,

scene: SCENE III.  London. Before the Tower.
speaker: GLOUCESTER
line: Here by the cheeks I'll drag thee up and down.

scene: SCENE III.  London. Before the Tower.
speaker: BISHOP OF WINCHESTER
line: Gloucester, thou wilt answer this before the pope.

scene: SCENE III.  London. Before the Tower.
speaker: GLOUCESTER
line: Winchester goose, I cry, a rope! a rope!

scene: SCENE III.  London. Before the Tower.
speaker: GLOUCESTER
line: Now beat them hence; why do you let them stay?

scene: SCENE III.  London. Before the Tower.
speaker: GLOUCESTER
line: Thee I'll chase hence, thou wolf in sheep's array.

scene: SCENE III.  London. Before the Tower.
speaker: GLOUCESTER
line: Out, tawny coats! out, scarlet hypocrite!

scene: SCENE III.  London. Before the Tower.
speaker: Mayor
line: Fie, lords! that you, being supreme magistrates,

scene: SCENE III.  London. Before the Tower.
speaker: Mayor
line: Thus contumeliously should break the peace!

scene: SCENE III.  London. Before the Tower.
speaker: GLOUCESTER
line: Peace, mayor! thou know'st little of my wrongs:

scene: SCENE III.  London. Before the Tower.
speaker: GLOUCESTER
line: Here's Beaufort, that regards nor God nor king,

scene: SCENE III.  London. Before the Tower.
speaker: GLOUCESTER
line: Hath here distrain'd the Tower to his use.

scene: SCENE III.  London. Before the Tower.
speaker: BISHOP OF WINCHESTER
line: Here's Gloucester, a foe to citizens,

scene: SCENE III.  London. Before the Tower.
speaker: BISHOP OF WINCHESTER
line: One that still motions war and never peace,

scene: SCENE III.  London. Before the Tower.
speaker: BISHOP OF WINCHESTER
line: O'ercharging your free purses with large fines,

scene: SCENE III.  London. Before the Tower.
speaker: BISHOP OF WINCHESTER
line: That seeks to overthrow religion,

scene: SCENE III.  London. Before the Tower.
speaker: BISHOP OF WINCHESTER
line: Because he is protector of the realm,

scene: SCENE III.  London. Before the Tower.
speaker: BISHOP OF WINCHESTER
line: And would have armour here out of the Tower,

scene: SCENE III.  London. Before the Tower.
speaker: BISHOP OF WINCHESTER
line: To crown himself king and suppress the prince.

scene: SCENE III.  London. Before the Tower.
speaker: GLOUCESTER
line: I will not answer thee with words, but blows.

scene: SCENE III.  London. Before the Tower.
speaker: Mayor
line: Naught rests for me in this tumultuous strife

scene: SCENE III.  London. Before the Tower.
speaker: Mayor
line: But to make open proclamation:

scene: SCENE III.  London. Before the Tower.
speaker: Mayor
line: Come, officer; as loud as e'er thou canst,

scene: SCENE III.  London. Before the Tower.
speaker: Mayor
line: Cry.

scene: SCENE III.  London. Before the Tower.
speaker: Officer
line: All manner of men assembled here in arms this day

scene: SCENE III.  London. Before the Tower.
speaker: Officer
line: against God's peace and the king's, we charge and

scene: SCENE III.  London. Before the Tower.
speaker: Officer
line: command you, in his highness' name, to repair to

scene: SCENE III.  London. Before the Tower.
speaker: Officer
line: your several dwelling-places; and not to wear,

scene: SCENE III.  London. Before the Tower.
speaker: Officer
line: handle, or use any sword, weapon, or dagger,

scene: SCENE III.  London. Before the Tower.
speaker: Officer
line: henceforward, upon pain of death.

scene: SCENE III.  London. Before the Tower.
speaker: GLOUCESTER
line: Cardinal, I'll be no breaker of the law:

scene: SCENE III.  London. Before the Tower.
speaker: GLOUCESTER
line: But we shall meet, and break our minds at large.

scene: SCENE III.  London. Before the Tower.
speaker: BISHOP OF WINCHESTER
line: Gloucester, we will meet; to thy cost, be sure:

scene: SCENE III.  London. Before the Tower.
speaker: BISHOP OF WINCHESTER
line: Thy heart-blood I will have for this day's work.

scene: SCENE III.  London. Before the Tower.
speaker: Mayor
line: I'll call for clubs, if you will not away.

scene: SCENE III.  London. Before the Tower.
speaker: Mayor
line: This cardinal's more haughty than the devil.

scene: SCENE III.  London. Before the Tower.
speaker: GLOUCESTER
line: Mayor, farewell: thou dost but what thou mayst.

scene: SCENE III.  London. Before the Tower.
speaker: BISHOP OF WINCHESTER
line: Abominable Gloucester, guard thy head;

scene: SCENE III.  London. Before the Tower.
speaker: BISHOP OF WINCHESTER
line: For I intend to have it ere long.

scene: SCENE III.  London. Before the Tower.
speaker: Mayor
line: See the coast clear'd, and then we will depart.

scene: SCENE III.  London. Before the Tower.
speaker: Mayor
line: Good God, these nobles should such stomachs bear!

scene: SCENE III.  London. Before the Tower.
speaker: Mayor
line: I myself fight not once in forty year.

speaker: Master-Gunner
line: Sirrah, thou know'st how Orleans is besieged,

speaker: Master-Gunner
line: And how the English have the suburbs won.

speaker: Boy
line: Father, I know; and oft have shot at them,

speaker: Boy
line: Howe'er unfortunate I miss'd my aim.

speaker: Master-Gunner
line: But now thou shalt not. Be thou ruled by me:

speaker: Master-Gunner
line: Chief master-gunner am I of this town;

speaker: Master-Gunner
line: Something I must do to procure me grace.

speaker: Master-Gunner
line: The prince's espials have informed me

speaker: Master-Gunner
line: How the English, in the suburbs close intrench'd,

speaker: Master-Gunner
line: Wont, through a secret grate of iron bars

speaker: Master-Gunner
line: In yonder tower, to overpeer the city,

speaker: Master-Gunner
line: And thence discover how with most advantage

speaker: Master-Gunner
line: They may vex us with shot, or with assault.

speaker: Master-Gunner
line: To intercept this inconvenience,

speaker: Master-Gunner
line: A piece of ordnance 'gainst it I have placed;

speaker: Master-Gunner
line: And even these three days have I watch'd,

speaker: Master-Gunner
line: If I could see them.

speaker: Master-Gunner
line: Now do thou watch, for I can stay no longer.

speaker: Master-Gunner
line: If thou spy'st any, run and bring me word;

speaker: Master-Gunner
line: And thou shalt find me at the governor's.

speaker: Boy
line: Father, I warrant you; take you no care;

speaker: Boy
line: I'll never trouble you, if I may spy them.

speaker: SALISBURY
line: Talbot, my life, my joy, again return'd!

speaker: SALISBURY
line: How wert thou handled being prisoner?

speaker: SALISBURY
line: Or by what means got'st thou to be released?

speaker: SALISBURY
line: Discourse, I prithee, on this turret's top.

speaker: TALBOT
line: The Duke of Bedford had a prisoner

speaker: TALBOT
line: Call'd the brave Lord Ponton de Santrailles;

speaker: TALBOT
line: For him was I exchanged and ransomed.

speaker: TALBOT
line: But with a baser man of arms by far

speaker: TALBOT
line: Once in contempt they would have barter'd me:

speaker: TALBOT
line: Which I, disdaining, scorn'd; and craved death,

speaker: TALBOT
line: Rather than I would be so vile esteem'd.

speaker: TALBOT
line: In fine, redeem'd I was as I desired.

speaker: TALBOT
line: But, O! the treacherous Fastolfe wounds my heart,

speaker: TALBOT
line: Whom with my bare fists I would execute,

speaker: TALBOT
line: If I now had him brought into my power.

speaker: SALISBURY
line: Yet tell'st thou not how thou wert entertain'd.

speaker: TALBOT
line: With scoffs and scorns and contumelious taunts.

speaker: TALBOT
line: In open market-place produced they me,

speaker: TALBOT
line: To be a public spectacle to all:

speaker: TALBOT
line: Here, said they, is the terror of the French,

speaker: TALBOT
line: The scarecrow that affrights our children so.

speaker: TALBOT
line: Then broke I from the officers that led me,

speaker: TALBOT
line: And with my nails digg'd stones out of the ground,

speaker: TALBOT
line: To hurl at the beholders of my shame:

speaker: TALBOT
line: My grisly countenance made others fly;

speaker: TALBOT
line: None durst come near for fear of sudden death.

speaker: TALBOT
line: In iron walls they deem'd me not secure;

speaker: TALBOT
line: So great fear of my name 'mongst them was spread,

speaker: TALBOT
line: That they supposed I could rend bars of steel,

speaker: TALBOT
line: And spurn in pieces posts of adamant:

speaker: TALBOT
line: Wherefore a guard of chosen shot I had,

speaker: TALBOT
line: That walked about me every minute-while;

speaker: TALBOT
line: And if I did but stir out of my bed,

speaker: TALBOT
line: Ready they were to shoot me to the heart.

speaker: SALISBURY
line: I grieve to hear what torments you endured,

speaker: SALISBURY
line: But we will be revenged sufficiently

speaker: SALISBURY
line: Now it is supper-time in Orleans:

speaker: SALISBURY
line: Here, through this grate, I count each one

speaker: SALISBURY
line: and view the Frenchmen how they fortify:

speaker: SALISBURY
line: Let us look in; the sight will much delight thee.

speaker: SALISBURY
line: Sir Thomas Gargrave, and Sir William Glansdale,

speaker: SALISBURY
line: Let me have your express opinions

speaker: SALISBURY
line: Where is best place to make our battery next.

speaker: GARGRAVE
line: I think, at the north gate; for there stand lords.

speaker: GLANSDALE
line: And I, here, at the bulwark of the bridge.

speaker: TALBOT
line: For aught I see, this city must be famish'd,

speaker: TALBOT
line: Or with light skirmishes enfeebled.

speaker: SALISBURY
line: O Lord, have mercy on us, wretched sinners!

speaker: GARGRAVE
line: O Lord, have mercy on me, woful man!

speaker: TALBOT
line: What chance is this that suddenly hath cross'd us?

speaker: TALBOT
line: Speak, Salisbury; at least, if thou canst speak:

speaker: TALBOT
line: How farest thou, mirror of all martial men?

speaker: TALBOT
line: One of thy eyes and thy cheek's side struck off!

speaker: TALBOT
line: Accursed tower! accursed fatal hand

speaker: TALBOT
line: That hath contrived this woful tragedy!

speaker: TALBOT
line: In thirteen battles Salisbury o'ercame;

speaker: TALBOT
line: Henry the Fifth he first train'd to the wars;

speaker: TALBOT
line: Whilst any trump did sound, or drum struck up,

speaker: TALBOT
line: His sword did ne'er leave striking in the field.

speaker: TALBOT
line: Yet livest thou, Salisbury? though thy speech doth fail,

speaker: TALBOT
line: One eye thou hast, to look to heaven for grace:

speaker: TALBOT
line: The sun with one eye vieweth all the world.

speaker: TALBOT
line: Heaven, be thou gracious to none alive,

speaker: TALBOT
line: If Salisbury wants mercy at thy hands!

speaker: TALBOT
line: Bear hence his body; I will help to bury it.

speaker: TALBOT
line: Sir Thomas Gargrave, hast thou any life?

speaker: TALBOT
line: Speak unto Talbot; nay, look up to him.

speaker: TALBOT
line: Salisbury, cheer thy spirit with this comfort;

speaker: TALBOT
line: Thou shalt not die whiles--

speaker: TALBOT
line: He beckons with his hand and smiles on me.

speaker: TALBOT
line: As who should say 'When I am dead and gone,

speaker: TALBOT
line: Remember to avenge me on the French.'

speaker: TALBOT
line: Plantagenet, I will; and like thee, Nero,

speaker: TALBOT
line: Play on the lute, beholding the towns burn:

speaker: TALBOT
line: Wretched shall France be only in my name.

speaker: TALBOT
line: What stir is this? what tumult's in the heavens?

speaker: TALBOT
line: Whence cometh this alarum and the noise?

speaker: Messenger
line: My lord, my lord, the French have gathered head:

speaker: Messenger
line: The Dauphin, with one Joan la Pucelle join'd,

speaker: Messenger
line: A holy prophetess new risen up,

speaker: Messenger
line: Is come with a great power to raise the siege.

speaker: TALBOT
line: Hear, hear how dying Salisbury doth groan!

speaker: TALBOT
line: It irks his heart he cannot be revenged.

speaker: TALBOT
line: Frenchmen, I'll be a Salisbury to you:

speaker: TALBOT
line: Pucelle or puzzel, dolphin or dogfish,

speaker: TALBOT
line: Your hearts I'll stamp out with my horse's heels,

speaker: TALBOT
line: And make a quagmire of your mingled brains.

speaker: TALBOT
line: Convey me Salisbury into his tent,

speaker: TALBOT
line: And then we'll try what these dastard Frenchmen dare.

speaker: TALBOT
line: Where is my strength, my valour, and my force?

speaker: TALBOT
line: Our English troops retire, I cannot stay them:

speaker: TALBOT
line: A woman clad in armour chaseth them.

speaker: TALBOT
line: Here, here she comes. I'll have a bout with thee;

speaker: TALBOT
line: Devil or devil's dam, I'll conjure thee:

speaker: TALBOT
line: Blood will I draw on thee, thou art a witch,

speaker: TALBOT
line: And straightway give thy soul to him thou servest.

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
line: Come, come, 'tis only I that must disgrace thee.

speaker: TALBOT
line: Heavens, can you suffer hell so to prevail?

speaker: TALBOT
line: My breast I'll burst with straining of my courage

speaker: TALBOT
line: And from my shoulders crack my arms asunder.

speaker: TALBOT
line: But I will chastise this high-minded strumpet.

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
line: Talbot, farewell; thy hour is not yet come:

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
line: I must go victual Orleans forthwith.

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
line: O'ertake me, if thou canst; I scorn thy strength.

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
line: Go, go, cheer up thy hungry-starved men;

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
line: Help Salisbury to make his testament:

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
line: This day is ours, as many more shall be.

speaker: TALBOT
line: My thoughts are whirled like a potter's wheel;

speaker: TALBOT
line: I know not where I am, nor what I do;

speaker: TALBOT
line: A witch, by fear, not force, like Hannibal,

speaker: TALBOT
line: Drives back our troops and conquers as she lists:

speaker: TALBOT
line: So bees with smoke and doves with noisome stench

speaker: TALBOT
line: Are from their hives and houses driven away.

speaker: TALBOT
line: They call'd us for our fierceness English dogs;

speaker: TALBOT
line: Now, like to whelps, we crying run away.

speaker: TALBOT
line: Hark, countrymen! either renew the fight,

speaker: TALBOT
line: Or tear the lions out of England's coat;

speaker: TALBOT
line: Renounce your soil, give sheep in lions' stead:

speaker: TALBOT
line: Sheep run not half so treacherous from the wolf,

speaker: TALBOT
line: Or horse or oxen from the leopard,

speaker: TALBOT
line: As you fly from your oft-subdued slaves.

speaker: TALBOT
line: It will not be: retire into your trenches:

speaker: TALBOT
line: You all consented unto Salisbury's death,

speaker: TALBOT
line: For none would strike a stroke in his revenge.

speaker: TALBOT
line: Pucelle is enter'd into Orleans,

speaker: TALBOT
line: In spite of us or aught that we could do.

speaker: TALBOT
line: O, would I were to die with Salisbury!

speaker: TALBOT
line: The shame hereof will make me hide my head.

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
line: Advance our waving colours on the walls;

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
line: Rescued is Orleans from the English

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
line: Thus Joan la Pucelle hath perform'd her word.

speaker: CHARLES
line: Divinest creature, Astraea's daughter,

speaker: CHARLES
line: How shall I honour thee for this success?

speaker: CHARLES
line: Thy promises are like Adonis' gardens

speaker: CHARLES
line: That one day bloom'd and fruitful were the next.

speaker: CHARLES
line: France, triumph in thy glorious prophetess!

speaker: CHARLES
line: Recover'd is the town of Orleans:

speaker: CHARLES
line: More blessed hap did ne'er befall our state.

speaker: REIGNIER
line: Why ring not out the bells aloud throughout the town?

speaker: REIGNIER
line: Dauphin, command the citizens make bonfires

speaker: REIGNIER
line: And feast and banquet in the open streets,

speaker: REIGNIER
line: To celebrate the joy that God hath given us.

speaker: ALENCON
line: All France will be replete with mirth and joy,

speaker: ALENCON
line: When they shall hear how we have play'd the men.

speaker: CHARLES
line: 'Tis Joan, not we, by whom the day is won;

speaker: CHARLES
line: For which I will divide my crown with her,

speaker: CHARLES
line: And all the priests and friars in my realm

speaker: CHARLES
line: Shall in procession sing her endless praise.

speaker: CHARLES
line: A statelier pyramis to her I'll rear

speaker: CHARLES
line: Than Rhodope's or Memphis' ever was:

speaker: CHARLES
line: In memory of her when she is dead,

speaker: CHARLES
line: Her ashes, in an urn more precious

speaker: CHARLES
line: Than the rich-jewel'd of Darius,

speaker: CHARLES
line: Transported shall be at high festivals

speaker: CHARLES
line: Before the kings and queens of France.

speaker: CHARLES
line: No longer on Saint Denis will we cry,

speaker: CHARLES
line: But Joan la Pucelle shall be France's saint.

speaker: CHARLES
line: Come in, and let us banquet royally,

speaker: CHARLES
line: After this golden day of victory.

speaker: Sergeant
line: Sirs, take your places and be vigilant:

speaker: Sergeant
line: If any noise or soldier you perceive

speaker: Sergeant
line: Near to the walls, by some apparent sign

speaker: Sergeant
line: Let us have knowledge at the court of guard.

speaker: First Sentinel
line: Sergeant, you shall.

speaker: First Sentinel
line: Thus are poor servitors,

speaker: First Sentinel
line: When others sleep upon their quiet beds,

speaker: First Sentinel
line: Constrain'd to watch in darkness, rain and cold.

speaker: TALBOT
line: Lord Regent, and redoubted Burgundy,

speaker: TALBOT
line: By whose approach the regions of Artois,

speaker: TALBOT
line: Wallon and Picardy are friends to us,

speaker: TALBOT
line: This happy night the Frenchmen are secure,

speaker: TALBOT
line: Having all day caroused and banqueted:

speaker: TALBOT
line: Embrace we then this opportunity

speaker: TALBOT
line: As fitting best to quittance their deceit

speaker: TALBOT
line: Contrived by art and baleful sorcery.

speaker: BEDFORD
line: Coward of France! how much he wrongs his fame,

speaker: BEDFORD
line: Despairing of his own arm's fortitude,

speaker: BEDFORD
line: To join with witches and the help of hell!

speaker: BURGUNDY
line: Traitors have never other company.

speaker: BURGUNDY
line: But what's that Pucelle whom they term so pure?

speaker: TALBOT
line: A maid, they say.

speaker: BEDFORD
line: A maid! and be so martial!

speaker: BURGUNDY
line: Pray God she prove not masculine ere long,

speaker: BURGUNDY
line: If underneath the standard of the French

speaker: BURGUNDY
line: She carry armour as she hath begun.

speaker: TALBOT
line: Well, let them practise and converse with spirits:

speaker: TALBOT
line: God is our fortress, in whose conquering name

speaker: TALBOT
line: Let us resolve to scale their flinty bulwarks.

speaker: BEDFORD
line: Ascend, brave Talbot; we will follow thee.

speaker: TALBOT
line: Not all together: better far, I guess,

speaker: TALBOT
line: That we do make our entrance several ways;

speaker: TALBOT
line: That, if it chance the one of us do fail,

speaker: TALBOT
